articles.headline: Solar Industry Borrows a Page, and a Party, From Tupperware
articles.snippet: Solar parties, like Tupperware parties, are being used by solar companies to sell their products to neighbors of homeowners who have installed the arrays.
articles.abstract: Solar parties, like Tupperware parties, are being used by solar companies to sell their products to neighbors of homeowners who have installed the arrays.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — The neighbors had gathered on the patio of a sun-baked ranch here, eager to hear the party’s hosts talk about their products and how they could enhance their lives. But in place of the timeworn arrangement of plastic storage containers or cosmetics on the coffee table, the couple was showing off an array of a different sort: the 32 solar panels on the roof.

articles.headline: Simpler Taxes Now, Growth Later
articles.snippet: Economists say the talk in Washington of raising additional tax revenue and cutting spending would most likely depress growth in the short term.
articles.abstract: Economists say the talk in Washington of raising additional tax revenue and cutting spending would most likely depress growth in the short term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers consider rolling back many of the $1 trillion a year in tax breaks now doled out to businesses and individuals, some are promising that streamlining the tax code will not only raise revenue, but also spur economic growth.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: Small Employers Weigh Impact of Providing Health Insurance
articles.snippet: Businesses like restaurants and hotels that rely heavily on low-income workers are trying to decide how to change their business models for the new health care law.
articles.abstract: Businesses like restaurants and hotels that rely heavily on low-income workers are trying to decide how to change their business models for the new health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many franchisees, Robert U. Mayfield, who owns five Dairy Queens in and around Austin, Tex., is always eager to expand and — no surprise — has had his eyes on opening a sixth DQ. But he said concerns about the new federal health care law had persuaded him to hold off.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: U.S. to Pay $3.8 Billion for Next Lot of F-35 Jets
articles.snippet: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle for 32 of the jets after a year of tense negotiations to lower costs.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle for 32 of the jets after a year of tense negotiations to lower costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle on Friday on the price of a fifth batch of F-35 fighter jets after a year of tense negotiations over how to lower costs.

articles.headline: In South Africa, Lethal Battles for Even Smallest of Political Posts
articles.snippet: Dozens of officials, including ward councilors, party leaders and mayors, have been killed in what has become a desperate, deadly struggle for power and its spoils.
articles.abstract: Dozens of officials, including ward councilors, party leaders and mayors, have been killed in what has become a desperate, deadly struggle for power and its spoils.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSHABENI, South Africa — It was, by all accounts, an ordinary small-town political meeting. The leaders of the local branch of the African National Congress gathered in September at a convent here to discuss candidates for a newly vacated seat on the ward council, the lowest-level elected position in South Africa.

articles.headline: Retail Frenzy: Prices on the Web Change Hourly
articles.snippet: Retail price wars online have entered a new era of speed and precision, creating a confusing landscape for shoppers in which prices leap and plummet on short notice.
articles.abstract: Retail price wars online have entered a new era of speed and precision, creating a confusing landscape for shoppers in which prices leap and plummet on short notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day before Thanksgiving, Amazon was offering a discounted price of $49.96 on a popular Xbox game, the same price as Walmart and 3 cents lower than Target.

articles.headline: Young Immigrants Say It’s Obama’s Time to Act
articles.snippet: A group that had worked to advance the prospects of youths without legal papers and helped mobilize Latinos who voted for President Obama now says it’s payback time.
articles.abstract: A group that had worked to advance the prospects of youths without legal papers and helped mobilize Latinos who voted for President Obama now says it’s payback time.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — It has been a good year for young immigrants living in the country without legal papers, the ones who call themselves Dreamers.

articles.headline: Amid Egypt’s Duel on Democracy, Morsi Calls for Vote
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi, whose recent tone and actions have reminded critics of his autocratic predecessor, set a referendum on a new constitution for Dec. 15.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi, whose recent tone and actions have reminded critics of his autocratic predecessor, set a referendum on a new constitution for Dec. 15.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi speaks darkly of imminent threats from a conspiracy of unnamed foreign enemies and corrupt businessmen. He vows to uncover counterrevolutionaries hiding under judicial robes. His advisers charge that loyalists of the former dictator have infiltrated the opposition, saying it would gladly sacrifice democracy to defeat the Islamists.

articles.headline: As Companies Seek Tax Deals, Governments Pay High Price
articles.snippet: States, cities and counties are giving up more than $80 billion a year to attract or keep companies and the jobs they provide. But officials and governments rarely track how many jobs follow, and many do not know the value of all their awards.
articles.abstract: States, cities and counties are giving up more than $80 billion a year to attract or keep companies and the jobs they provide. But officials and governments rarely track how many jobs follow, and many do not know the value of all their awards.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the end, the money that towns across America gave General Motors did not matter.

articles.headline: In an F.H.A. Checkup, a Startling Number
articles.snippet: The Federal Housing Administration may be headed for a rescue, with a sudden, steep decline in a mortgage insurance fund’s value — a reminder that the housing crisis is still with us.
articles.abstract: The Federal Housing Administration may be headed for a rescue, with a sudden, steep decline in a mortgage insurance fund’s value — a reminder that the housing crisis is still with us.
articles.lead_paragraph: DO we have another Fannie or Freddie on our hands — another mortgage giant headed for a rescue?

articles.headline: Flow of Arms to Syria Through Iraq Persists, to U.S. Dismay
articles.snippet: Iraqi airspace has emerged as a main supply route for weapons from Iran, which has an enormous stake in Syria, at a time when President Bashar al-Assad is under increasing pressure from rebel fighters.
articles.abstract: Iraqi airspace has emerged as a main supply route for weapons from Iran, which has an enormous stake in Syria, at a time when President Bashar al-Assad is under increasing pressure from rebel fighters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American effort to stem the flow of Iranian arms to Syria has faltered because of Iraq’s reluctance to inspect aircraft carrying the weapons through its airspace, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Eric Schmitt and Tim Arango

articles.headline: John McAfee Plays Hide-and-Seek in Belize
articles.snippet: Sought by the police in Belize as a “person of interest” in the investigation of a neighbor’s murder, the tech legend John McAfee has moved his noisy life underground.
articles.abstract: Sought by the police in Belize as a “person of interest” in the investigation of a neighbor’s murder, the tech legend John McAfee has moved his noisy life underground.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMBERGRIS CAYE, Belize

articles.headline: Mortgage Catch Pushes Widows Into Foreclosure
articles.snippet: Just as the housing market is recovering, a growing group of homeowners — widows over 50 whose husbands held the mortgage — are losing their homes to foreclosure.
articles.abstract: Just as the housing market is recovering, a growing group of homeowners — widows over 50 whose husbands held the mortgage — are losing their homes to foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Geraldine Bates lost her husband to kidney failure last year. Now, she has fallen behind on her mortgage payments and is terrified that she will lose her home in Jacksonville, Fla.

articles.headline: In Panicky Russia, It’s Official: End of World Is Not Near
articles.snippet: As rumors of an impending apocalypse, prompted by the Mayan calendar, stir anxiety in Russia, the government has stepped in to encourage calm.
articles.abstract: As rumors of an impending apocalypse, prompted by the Mayan calendar, stir anxiety in Russia, the government has stepped in to encourage calm.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There are scattered reports of unusual behavior from across Russia’s nine time zones.

articles.headline: Trusted Aide to Obama Faces Test in Budget Showdown
articles.snippet: Quiet, religious and fiercely meticulous, President Obama’s chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, may be the most unassuming power broker in Washington.
articles.abstract: Quiet, religious and fiercely meticulous, President Obama’s chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, may be the most unassuming power broker in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama was locked in painful spending negotiations with House Republicans last spring, his exceedingly meticulous budget director, Jacob J. Lew, went to the Oval Office to propose some complex budget changes. As Mr. Lew delved deeper and deeper into the numbers, Mr. Obama put up his hand, signaling him to stop.

articles.headline: A Stalwart of Time Inc. Packs Up
articles.snippet: John Huey, the editor in chief of Time Inc., will vacate his office at the year’s end and says there is little he will miss about the job.
articles.abstract: John Huey, the editor in chief of Time Inc., will vacate his office at the year’s end and says there is little he will miss about the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the decade I’ve covered John Huey, I’d never once been to his magisterial office on the 34th floor of the Time & Life building. It is large and imposing in a way its occupant is not, an unlikely landing spot for an old newspaper hack. On the wall is a photograph of William Faulkner, “the patron saint of all hard-drinking Southern writers,” as Mr. Huey, a native of Atlanta, describes him.

articles.headline: Some Analysts Doubt Dire Predictions on Tax Increase Fallout
articles.snippet: Judging from tax changes in the past, some economists see a mostly mild effect on markets if tax rates on dividends and capital gains rise at the end of the year, as the White House has proposed.
articles.abstract: Judging from tax changes in the past, some economists see a mostly mild effect on markets if tax rates on dividends and capital gains rise at the end of the year, as the White House has proposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: As anxious investors assess their portfolios in light of expected tax increases on investment income, hedge fund manager Douglas Kass has a simple message: Relax.

articles.headline: Ford Redoubles Effort to Reawaken Its Sleepy Lincoln Brand
articles.snippet: On Monday, Ford will formally rechristen the Lincoln brand and introduce a television spot that begins with an image of President Lincoln, stovepipe hat and all.
articles.abstract: On Monday, Ford will formally rechristen the Lincoln brand and introduce a television spot that begins with an image of President Lincoln, stovepipe hat and all.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — In the fiercely competitive world of luxury cars, the Ford Motor Company’s Lincoln brand has long been stuck in the slow lane, with stodgy models, older buyers and a distinct lack of pizazz.

articles.headline: Lines Blur as Texas Gives Industries a Bonanza
articles.snippet: Texas offers more incentives to attract business than any other state, but questions remain about who benefits more, the companies or the people of Texas.
articles.abstract: Texas offers more incentives to attract business than any other state, but questions remain about who benefits more, the companies or the people of Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The Preston Hollow neighborhood has been home to many of Texas’ rich and powerful — George and Laura Bush, Mark Cuban, T. Boone Pickens, Ross Perot. So it is hardly surprising that a recent political fund-raiser was held there on the back terrace of a 20,000-square-foot home overlooking lush gardens with life-size bronze statues of the host’s daughters.

articles.headline: A Feisty Start-Up Is Met With Regulatory Snarl
articles.snippet: Uber, which is being sued by San Francisco cabdrivers and Chicago car services over its hire-a-car smartphone app, says the laws holding it back are anticompetitive. And it has plenty of fans.
articles.abstract: Uber, which is being sued by San Francisco cabdrivers and Chicago car services over its hire-a-car smartphone app, says the laws holding it back are anticompetitive. And it has plenty of fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Summoning a taxi or car service with your smartphone feels like the future. City governments around the world can agree on that. But many of them are proposing new rules that would run Uber, one of the most prominent ride-requesting apps, off the road.

articles.headline: DVR Use One Factor in Networks’ Low Ratings
articles.snippet: CBS, ABC and Fox have all had decreases in ratings, explained partly by the shift toward delayed viewing and partly by a generally weak slate of new shows.
articles.abstract: CBS, ABC and Fox have all had decreases in ratings, explained partly by the shift toward delayed viewing and partly by a generally weak slate of new shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you ask several of the top programmers in network television what is going wrong with their ratings this season, they offer a litany of answers: jarring schedule disruptions from debates, election night and Hurricane Sandy, for instance, as well as the ever-increasing defections toward delayed viewing and away from the nightly schedules that have defined network prime time since the days of radio.

articles.headline: Collaboration in Gaza Leads to Grisly Fate
articles.snippet: Recent vigilante-style killings of seven Palestinians suspected of providing intelligence to Israel highlighted the pathetic plight of collaborators.
articles.abstract: Recent vigilante-style killings of seven Palestinians suspected of providing intelligence to Israel highlighted the pathetic plight of collaborators.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAFAH, Gaza Strip — When Fadel Shalouf’s family went to pick up his body at the morgue the day after he was executed on a busy Gaza street corner, they found his hands still cuffed behind his back. Hamas, the militant faction that rules Gaza, did not provide a van to carry the body to burial, so they laid him on two men’s laps in the back of a sedan.

articles.headline: Criticized as Weak in Past Talks, Obama Takes Harder Line
articles.snippet: President Obama has emerged as a different kind of negotiator in the past week or two, frustrating Republicans on the other side of the bargaining table.
articles.abstract: President Obama has emerged as a different kind of negotiator in the past week or two, frustrating Republicans on the other side of the bargaining table.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amid demands from Republicans that President Obama propose detailed new spending cuts to avert the year-end fiscal crisis, his answer boils down to this: you first.

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Trader Faces Inquiry on Possible Manipulation
articles.snippet: Glenn Hadden, who is now head of the global interest rates desk at Morgan Stanley, is under investigation over his trading in Treasury futures while at Goldman Sachs, according to a regulatory filing.
articles.abstract: Glenn Hadden, who is now head of the global interest rates desk at Morgan Stanley, is under investigation over his trading in Treasury futures while at Goldman Sachs, according to a regulatory filing.
articles.lead_paragraph: On paper, Glenn Hadden seemed to be the ideal person to run a large bond trading operation at Morgan Stanley when he was hired in early 2011. Mr. Hadden, a former Goldman partner, was one of the most profitable bond traders on Wall Street.

articles.headline: UBS Is Reported to Be Near a Deal on Rate Rigging
articles.snippet: The Swiss banking giant UBS is expected to pay American and British fines of more than $450 million to settle claims that it reported false rates to increase its profit, according to officials briefed on the matter.
articles.abstract: The Swiss banking giant UBS is expected to pay American and British fines of more than $450 million to settle claims that it reported false rates to increase its profit, according to officials briefed on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: UBS, the Swiss banking giant, is close to reaching settlements with American and British authorities over the manipulation of interest rates, the latest case in a multiyear investigation that has rattled the financial industry and spurred a public outcry for broad reform.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott
